title: Philippines: Teaching Kids to Be Disaster-Ready
summary: Manila - Three community leaders came together to reach out to more than 250 children and help them and their families better respond in times of typhoons and other natural disasters.
tag-1: Philippines: Teaching Kids to Be Disaster-Ready
tag-3: Manila – Three community leaders came together to reach out to more than 250 children and help them and their families better respond in times of typhoons and other natural disasters.
tag-4: Citi Philippines, Museo Pambata and the Philippine Business for Social Progress (PBSP) hosted students of Tipas Elementary School and Maliksi Elementary School along with their teachers last August 31. These students are currently enrolled in the fourth and fifth grades and were delighted at the opportunity to visit Museo Pambata, the country's premier children's museum.
tag-5: The day's activities began with a guided tour of Museo Pambata, where the students were encouraged to interact with the exhibits in the different theme rooms, including one of a simulated rainforest and coastal area. They also spent time in "I Love My Planet Earth" room, which features exhibits on climate change and other environmental issues, plus tips on how everyone can do their share in saving the planet.
tag-6: These proved to be the ideal backdrop for the next set of activities, including a talk from the Philippine National Red Cross on disaster preparedness. Red Cross Volunteer JC Garcia engaged the students and teachers on how to respond during emergency situations. The students were taught what to do before, during and after typhoons and earthquakes. To keep the lecture more interesting, the instructor conducted games related to nature topics.
tag-7: After the talk, Museo Pambata presented a shadow story-telling, entitled Bahay Buhay (Home Life). The story aimed to raise the awareness of children on human-made disasters and understand the importance of maintaining a home for all living creatures.
tag-8: Volunteers from Citi along with representatives from PBSP and Museo Pambata and teachers from the partner schools guided the students during the activities.
tag-9: Citi Country Officer for the Philippines Batara Sianturi welcomed all the participants and explored the museum together with the students. "We are pleased to support Museo Pambata and make it possible for these students to visit the museum for the first time and have a fun learning experience. I also want to acknowledge the partnership of Philippine Business for Social Progress for their assistance in coordinating the activities with the beneficiary schools."
tag-10: Sianturi was joined by PBSP regional program coordinator for education Panielo Tunac and Museo Pambata executive director Maricel Montero during the welcome ceremonies.
tag-11: At the end of the event, Citi distributed disaster-ready kits to the children and teachers. Each kit, dubbed a Grab and Go pack, has a raincoat, flashlight, water bottle, whistle and other items that will come in handy should one need to leave his or her home or aid in a rescue mission.
tag-12: In a show of hands, all the students and teachers confirmed that their homes and communities were affected during typhoon Maring. Some had to evacuate their homes for safety and were still unable to return weeks later.
tag-13: "Citi, both our employees and as an institution, are deeply committed to environmental sustainability. We trust the activities opened the minds of the students on how they can protect themselves during disaster situations, and also come to their families' aid when needed. Another message we hoped to impart is the urgency for all of us to do our share in protecting the environment," said Sianturi.
